content: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <!DOCTYPE metadata SYSTEM "http://thor-f5.er.usgs.gov/ngtoc/metadata/fgdc-std-001-1998.dtd"> <metadata>   <idinfo>     <citation>       <citeinfo>         <origin>U.S. Geological Survey</origin>         <pubdate>200506</pubdate>         <title>USGS Small-scale Dataset - Bathymetry of North America 200506 GeoTIFF</title>         <geoform>Raster digital data</geoform>         <pubinfo>           <pubplace>Reston, VA</pubplace>           <publish>U.S. Geological Survey</publish>         </pubinfo>         <onlink>http://dds.cr.usgs.gov/pub/data/nationalatlas/bathymi3kml_nt00229.tar.gz</onlink>         <lworkcit>           <citeinfo>             <origin>U.S. Geological Survey</origin>             <pubdate>2005</pubdate>             <title>Small-scale Datasets</title>             <onlink>https://www.sciencebase.gov/catalog/item/532c5b23e4b0cd7393d07783</onlink>           </citeinfo>         </lworkcit>       </citeinfo>     </citation>     <descript>       <abstract> The Bathymetry of North America map layer shows depth ranges using colors.  The image was derived from the National Geophysical Data Center's ETOPO2  elevation data, which is an elevation database gridded at 2-minute  resolution, containing elevation and bathymetry for the world.  The image  was produced from the October 2001 data set.  </abstract>       <purpose> The bathymetry image was developed to portray ocean depths around North  America. This image is intended for visual purposes only.  The original  ETOPO2 data must be used for conducting analysis and determining specific  bathymetric values.  </purpose>       <supplinf> This image contains color tints in RGB color space.  For access to the  original 2 byte data, please visit the National Geophysical Data Center  web site mentioned below.    The associated world file is included as part of the GeoTIFF.  The  contents of the world file are:  >3107.6802  >0.000000  >0.000000  >-3107.6802  >-6084141.6440  >4487139.6139    The following projection file can be used when using ESRI's ArcGIS to view  the GeoTIFF (any line breaks should be removed):  PROJCS["NAD_1983_Lambert_Azimuthal_Equal_Area",GEOGCS  ["GCS_Sphere_ARC_INFO",DATUM["D_Sphere_ARC_INFO",SPHEROID  ["Sphere_ARC_INFO",6370997.0,0.0]],PRIMEM["Greenwich",0.0],  UNIT["Degree",0.0174532925199433]],PROJECTION  ["Lambert_Azimuthal_Equal_Area"],PARAMETER["False_Easting",0.0],  PARAMETER["False_Northing",0.0],PARAMETER["Central_Meridian",  -100.0],PARAMETER["Latitude_Of_Origin",45.0],UNIT["Meter",1.0]]  ; {"gdaId" : 6065693}</supplinf>     </descript>     <timeperd> <title>Bathymetric Shaded Relief of North America</title>         <pubinfo>           <pubplace>Reston, VA</pubplace>           <publish>National Atlas of the United States</publish>         </pubinfo>         <onlink> http://nationalatlas.gov/atlasftp.html?openChapters=chpgeol#chpgeol  </onlink>       </citeinfo>     </crossref>   </idinfo>   <dataqual>     <logic>No tests for logical consistency have been performed on this map layer.</logic>     <complete> Data completeness reflects the content of the original ETOPO2 elevation  data.  </complete>     <lineage>       <srcinfo>         <srccite>           <citeinfo>             <origin>National Geophysical Data Center</origin>             <pubdate>200110</pubdate>             <title>ETOPO2 Global 2' Elevations</title>             <pubinfo>               <pubplace>Boulder, CO, USA</pubplace>               <publish>National Geophysical Data Center</publish>             </pubinfo>             <onlink>http://www.ngdc.noaa.gov/mgg/image/2minrelief.html</onlink>           </citeinfo>         </srccite>         <typesrc>Online</typesrc>         <srctime>           <timeinfo>             <sngdate>               <caldate>2001</caldate>             </sngdate>           </timeinfo>           <srccurr>Publication date</srccurr>         </srctime>         <srccitea>NGDC - ETOPO2</srccitea>         <srccontr>Elevation information.</srccontr>       </srcinfo>       <procstep>         <procdesc> The ETOPO2 dataset was downloaded from the National Geophysical Data  Center web site using their GEODAS Grid Translator Design-a-Grid  interface.  This interface allows a user to create custom grids.  Users  can access the web interface at  http://www.ngdc.noaa.gov/mgg/gdas/gd_designagrid.html. The following  grid parameters were used:  >Grid Database:                   ETOPO2 2-minute Global Relief  >Latitude/Longitude Area Bounds:  90\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd0'N to 90\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd0'S, 180\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd0'W to 180\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd0'E  >Grid Cell Size:                  2 minutes  >Grid Cell Value Parameters:      2-byte integers, whole meters  >Grid Format:                     ASCII raster format, Arc header    The downloaded grid was converted to an ArcInfo grid using the  ArcToolbox import to raster interface.  ArcToolbox was also used to  define the initial coordinate system as Geographic (Lat/Lon) with units  in decimal degrees, and the datum as WGS 1984.  East and west grids were  derived from the main grid using the ArcInfo command GRIDCLIP.  The  east grid coverage was from 150 degrees to 180 degrees longitude and 0  degrees to 90 degrees latitude.  The west grid coverage was from 0  degrees to -180 degrees longitude and 0 degrees to 90 degrees latitude.  The ArcInfo command GRIDSHIFT was used to shift each grid 40 degrees  east, moving all data into the Western hemisphere.  This data processing  step was necessary due to the inability of ArcInfo to project raster  data across the 180-degree longitude line.  The ArcInfo Grid command  MERGE was used to combine the two grids into one grid.  This grid was  projected into the Lambert Azimuthal Equal Area projection, centered on  100 degrees West, 45 degrees North. The .prj file used in the Arc  PROJECT command contained these parameters:  > INPUT  > PROJECTION GEOGRAPHIC  > UNITS DD  > PARAMETERS  > OUTPUT  > PROJECTION LAMBERT_AZIMUTHAL  > UNITS METERS  > XSHIFT 0.0  > YSHIFT 0.0  > PARAMETERS  > 0.0  > -60 0 0  > 45 0 0  > 0.0  > 0.0  > END  >  Using a center of longitude of 60 degrees West in the projection  parameters creates an actual center of 100 degrees West due to the grid  shift of 40 degrees.  After projecting the data, the ArcInfo command  PROJECTDEFINE was used to reset the central meridian to 100 degrees  West.  The ArcInfo command GRIDCLIP was used to clip the grid to match  the dimensions used for National Atlas of the United States data.    The bathymetric image was created by converting the depths from meters  to feet, classifying the data into depth ranges, and then assigning an  RGB color to each range, as shown below.  The file was converted to TIFF  format using the command GRIDIMAGE.  >Depth Range         Index  Red    Green   Blue  >From      To  >-28300    -16000      1    53     146     214  >-15999    -12000      2    87     159     220  >-11999    -9000       3    124    180     231  >-8999     -6000       4    146    194     237  >-5999     -3000       5    170    212     243  >-2999     -1500       6    186    219     247  >-1499     -750        7    200    228     251  >-749      20320       8    216    236     252  The lightest color tint (index 8) extends across the land area.  </procdesc>         <srcused>NGDC - ETOPO2</srcused>         <procdate>200504</procdate>       </procstep>     </lineage>   </dataqual>   <spdoinfo>     <direct>Raster</direct>     <rastinfo>       <rasttype>Grid
